case_name: Ram Chandra Aggarwal and Kedar Prasad Aggarwal v. Brij Gopal Binani

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 113 of 1965 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION- Criminal Appeal No. 113 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated October 26, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 803 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 26, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 803 of 1963.

facts.text: Proceedings under s. 145, Cr. P.C. were initiated by a Magistrate on the basis of a report of a police officer.

anchor.surface_text: Proceedings under s. 145, Cr. P.C. were initiated by a Magistrate on the basis of a report of a police officer to the effect that a dispute likely to cause a breach of the peace exists concerning a plot of land situate within the jurisdiction of the Magistrate between the parties mentioned in the report and praying for appropriate action under S. 145 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Dispute likely to cause breach of peace exists concerning a plot of land within Magistrate's jurisdiction between parties mentioned in police report.

anchor.surface_text: to the effect that a dispute likely to cause a breach of the peace exists concerning a plot of land situate within the jurisdiction of the Magistrate between the parties mentioned in the report and praying for appropriate action under S. 145 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Magistrate made preliminary order under s. 145, Cr. P.C., attached the property and called upon parties to adduce evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate upon being satisfied about the possibility of a breach of the peace made a preliminary order under s. 145, Cr. P.C., attached the property to which the dispute related and called upon the parties to adduce evidence in respect of their respective claims.

facts.text: Magistrate recorded evidence but was unable to decide which party was in possession on the date of preliminary order and within two months thereof.

anchor.surface_text: In due course he recorded the evidence but he was unable to make up his mind as to which of the parties was in possession on the date of the preliminary order and within two months thereof.

facts.text: Magistrate referred the case under s. 146 of Cr. P.C. to a civil court for decision on possession.

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, referred the case under s. 146 1  of the Cr. P. C. to a civil court for decision, as to which of the parties was in possession at the material point of time and in the meanwhile directed that the attachment of the Property shall continue.

facts.text: Reference went to the court of the Munsiff within whose territorial jurisdiction the property was situate.

anchor.surface_text: The reference went to the court of the Munson within whose territorial jurisdiction the property was situate.

facts.text: Brij Gopal Binani, respondent No. 2, made application to District Judge under s. 24, C.P.C. for transfer of the case to some other court.

anchor.surface_text: But thereafter one of the parties Brij Gopal Binani, respondent No. 2 before us, made an application to the District Judge under S. 24, C.P.C. for transfer of the case to some other court.

facts.text: Ground for transfer: in execution case out of which s.145 proceedings arose, same Munsiff made order against Brij Gopal Binani depriving him of costs.

anchor.surface_text: The, ground given was that in the execution case out of which proceedings under s. 145, Cr.P.C. had arisen, the same Munsiff had. made an order against him depriving him of costs.

facts.text: Munsiff had no objection to the transfer.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsiff having no objection to the transfer the District Judge transferred the case to the court of another Munsiff.

facts.text: District Judge transferred the case to the court of another Munsiff.

anchor.surface_text: the District Judge transferred the case to the court of another Munsiff.

facts.text: Ram Chandra Aggarwal and Kedar Prasad Aggarwal, the appellants, acquiesced in the order of transfer and did not raise any question as to the jurisdiction of the transferee court.

anchor.surface_text: The opposite parties, that. is, the appellants before us Ram Chandra Aggarwal and Kedar Prasad Aggarwal acquiesced in the order of transfer and did not raise any question as to the jurisdiction of the, transferee court to-hear and-- decide the reference.

facts.text: Evidence was led by both sides before transferee court and finding given in favour of second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually evidence was led by both sides and a finding given by the transferee court. This finding was in favour of the second respondent.

facts.text: Magistrate held that second respondent was in possession at relevant date and passed order under s. 145(6), Cr. P.C.

anchor.surface_text: After receiving the finding the I Magistrate heard the-parties and held that it was the second respondent who was in possession at the relevant date and passed an order under s. 145 6 , Cr. P.C. pursuant thereto.

facts.text: Appellants preferred revision application before Court of Sessions raising objection for first time that civil court decision was nullity due to lack of territorial jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: A revision application was preferred by the appellants before the court of Sessions in which the objection was taken for the first time that the decision of the civil court was a nullity because it had no territorial jurisdic- tion over the subject-matter of the dispute.

facts.text: Sessions Judge rejected contentions on ground they were not raised earlier.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge who heard the revision application rejected these contentions on the ground that they were not raised earlier.

facts.text: Appellants took matter to High Court in revision on ground s.24 CPC not available for reference under s.146 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then took the matter to the High Court in revision. The appellants rested their revision application on the sole ground that s. 24, C.P.C. was not available in respect of a reference under s. 146 1  Cr. P.C.

facts.text: High Court negatived both grounds of attack by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived both the grounds on which the contention was based.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The only point which falls to be decided in this appeal by certificate granted by the High Court at Allahabad is whether the District Judge has jurisdiction under s. 24 of the Code of Civil Procedure to transfer a reference made by a Magistrate to a particular civil court under s. 146 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to another civil court.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Mudholkar, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mudholkar, J.

Proceedings under s. 145, Cr. P.C. were initiated by a Magistrate on the basis of a report of a police officer to the effect that a dispute likely to cause a breach of the peace exists concerning a plot of land situate within the jurisdiction of the Magistrate between the parties mentioned in the report and praying for appropriate action under S. 145 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

concepts.unlisted_description: Proceedings to prevent breach of peace regarding disputed possession

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate upon being satisfied about the possibility of a breach of the peace made a preliminary order under s. 145, Cr. P.C., attached the property to which the dispute related and called upon the parties to adduce evidence in respect of their respective claims. In due course he recorded the evidence but he was unable to make up his mind as to which of the parties was in possession on the date of the preliminary order and within two months thereof. He, therefore, referred the case under s. 146 1  of the Cr. P. C. to a civil court for decision, as to which of the parties was in possession at the material point of time and in the meanwhile directed that the attachment of the Property shall continue.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers Magistrate to refer possession question to civil court of competent jurisdiction when unable to decide; reference is to a constituted court, not persona designata.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mudholkar, J. The only point which falls to be decided in this appeal by certificate granted by the High Court at Allahabad is whether the District Judge has jurisdiction under s. 24 of the Code of Civil Procedure to transfer a reference made by a Magistrate to a particular civil court under s. 146 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to another civil court.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to transfer of reference under s.146 CrPC as it is a 'proceeding' pending in subordinate civil court; District Judge has jurisdiction to transfer.

anchor.surface_text: Though this decision was concerned with the meaning of the words civil proceeding used in Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution the reasoning behind it sufficiently repels the extreme contention of Mr., Goyal that a proceeding stemming from a criminal matter must always bear the stamp of a criminal proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court negatived both the grounds on which the contention was based. On behalf of the appellants Mr. Goyal has reiterated both the contentions. In fairness to Mr. Goyal it must be said that his attack on the order of the District Judge transferring the case under s. 24, C.P.C. was based more on the ground that the reference under s. 146 1  Cr. P.C. is not a civil proceeding than on the ground that the reference was to a persona designata.

arguments.claim: Reference under s.146 is to constituted court, not persona designata.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. R. L. Iyengar who appears for the State conceded that a reference under s. 146 1  is to a constituted court and not to a persona designata.

arguments.court_reasoning: cites Balakrishna Udayar, Central Talkies; s.146 refers to court of competent jurisdiction

arguments.claim: s.146 CrPC reference enlarges ordinary jurisdiction of constituted civil court, not persona designata.

anchor.surface_text: When a special or local law provides for an adjudication to be made by a constituted court... the reference cannot be said to be to a persona designata.

arguments.claim: Proceeding before civil court on s.146 reference is civil proceeding governed by CPC rules.

anchor.surface_text: when a legal right is in dispute and the ordinary courts of the country are seized of such dispute the courts are governed by the ordinary rules of procedure applicable to them.

arguments.claim: Magistrate does not confer criminal jurisdiction on civil court by reference under s.146.

anchor.surface_text: when the magistrate refers the question to a civil court he does not confer a part of his criminal jurisdiction upon the civil court. There is no provision under which he can clothe a court... with criminal jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: s.24(1)(b) CPC applies to 'other proceeding' pending in subordinate court, including s.146 reference.

anchor.surface_text: All that we are concerned with in this case is whether the provisions of s. 24 1 b of the Code of Civil Procedure are available with respect to a proceeding arising out of a reference under s. 146 1 , Cr. P.C.

arguments.claim: 'Proceeding' in s.24 CPC has comprehensive meaning including all matters for judicial adjudication, not confined to civil proceedings.

holdings.text: A reference under s. 146(1) Cr. P.C. is to a constituted civil court of competent jurisdiction and not to a persona designata.

anchor.surface_text: However, as he did not wish to abandon the other point we must deal with it even though Mr. R. L. Iyengar who appears for the State conceded that a reference under s. 146 1  is to a constituted court and not to a persona designata. In Balakrishna Udayar v. Vasudeva Aiyar 1  Lord Atkinson has pointed out the difference between a persona designata and a legal tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded by State counsel; distinguished by precedents (Balakrishna Udayar, Central Talkies); s.146 refers to court, enlarging its jurisdiction; well settled law.

holdings.text: When a legal right is in dispute before ordinary civil courts, they are governed by ordinary rules of procedure applicable thereto, regardless of origin in criminal proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: This decision ignores the vast body of authority which is to the effect that when a legal right is in dispute and the ordinary courts of the country are seized of such dispute the courts are governed by the ordinary rules of procedure applicable to them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects criminal character retention; cites Privy Council (Adaikappa Chettiar, Maung Ba Thaw) and SC cases (South Asia Industries, Narayan Row); proceeding before civil court is civil.

holdings.text: The Magistrate does not confer criminal jurisdiction on the civil court by reference under s.146 Cr. P.C.; civil court exercises its own jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, the Magistrate, while discharging his function under the Code of Criminal Procedure under s. 145 1 , would be exercising his criminal jurisdiction because that is the only kind of jurisdiction which the Code confers upon the magistrates but when the magistrate refers the question to a civil court he does not confer a part of his criminal jurisdiction upon the civil court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No provision allows Magistrate to clothe civil court with criminal jurisdiction; cites Privy Council decisions rejecting delegation theory.

holdings.text: s.146(1B) Cr. P.C. expressly bars appeal/review/revision from civil court's finding; does not alter civil character of proceeding.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-section (1B) is new express limitation; pre-enactment, remedies would apply if civil; bar is specific, not definitional of proceeding's nature.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.24(1)(b) CPC are available for transfer of a proceeding arising out of reference under s.146(1) Cr. P.C. by District Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Other proceeding' comprehensively includes all judicial adjudications in subordinate courts, not limited to suits/appeals/civil; cites Privy Council/SC; approves Kochadai Naidu (Madras HC).

holdings.text: Expression 'proceeding' in s.24(1)(b) CPC has comprehensive meaning including all matters for judicial adjudication, not confined to civil proceedings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual interpretation of 'other proceeding'; broad to effectuate transfer power; consistent with precedents on civil court procedures.

holdings.text: Proceeding under s.141 CPC applicability to s.146 reference not decided, but good authority supports it as civil proceeding.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not essential for s.24 issue; cites Allahabad FB (Maha Ram), SC (Munshi Ram) applying s.141 to non-suit proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In BalakrishnaUdayar v. Vasudeva Aiyar 1 Lord Atkinson has pointed out teh difference between a persona designata and a legal tribunal. The difference is in this that the determinations of a persona designata are

precedents.cited_proposition: difference between a persona designata and a legal tribunal

precedents.citation: central Talkies Ltd. v. Dwarka Prasad 2

anchor.surface_text: In the central Talkies Ltd. v. Dwarka Prasad 2 this Court has accepted the meaning given to the expression persona designata in Osborns Concise Law Dictionary. 4th edn. p. 263 as eta person who is pointed out or described as an individual, as opposed to a person ascertained as a member of a class, or as filling a particular characters Section 146

precedents.case_name: Central Talkies Ltd v Dwarka Prasad

precedents.citation: Chatur Mohan v. Ram Behari Dixit. 1

anchor.surface_text: This question is well settled. It is, therefore, unnecessary to say anything more on this part of the case except that cases dealing with the point have been well summarised in the recent decision in Chatur Mohan v. Ram Behari Dixit. 1 . Now, as to the argument based on the ground that the pro- ceeding before the civil court is not a civil proceeding, Mr. Goyals contention is that since the proceeding before the criminal court under s. 145 is a criminal proceeding any matter arising out of it, including a reference to a civil court, does not lose its initial character of a criminal proceeding.

precedents.case_name: Chatur Mohan v Ram Behari Dixit
precedents.cited_proposition: summarises cases on persona designata vs constituted court

precedents.citation: Sri Sheonath Prasad v. City Magistrate, Varanasi.  2

anchor.surface_text: In support of his contention he has placed strong reliance upon the observations of Jagdish Sahai J., in Sri Sheonath Prasad v. City Magistrate, Varanasi.  2  In that case the learned Judge was called upon to consider the meaning of the expression civil court of competent jurisdiction occurring in s. 146 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

precedents.case_name: Sri Sheonath Prasad v City Magistrate Varanasi
precedents.cited_proposition: proceeding on reference to civil court retains criminal character; no pecuniary jurisdiction needed
precedents.cited_holding: a proceeding even on reference made to a civil court retains its old moorings and does not change its character from a criminal proceeding to a civil proceeding

anchor.surface_text: This decision ignores the vast body of authority which is to the effect that when a legal right- is in dispute and the ordinary courts of the country are seized of such dispute the courts are governed by the ordinary rules of procedure applicable to them. Two of the decisions are Adaikappa Chettiar v. Chandrasekharca Theyar 1  and Maung Ba Thaw v. Ma Pin 1

precedents.cited_proposition: ordinary courts seized of legal right disputes governed by ordinary rules of procedure

precedents.citation: Maung Ba Thaw v. Ma Pin 1

anchor.surface_text: Two of the decisions are Adaikappa Chettiar v. Chandrasekharca Theyar 1  and Maung Ba Thaw v. Ma Pin 1  and also a decision of this Court which proceeds upon the same view.

precedents.case_name: Maung Ba Thaw v Ma Pin
precedents.cited_proposition: ordinary courts seized of legal right disputes governed by ordinary rules of procedure

precedents.citation: South Asia Industries  P  Ltd. v. S. B. Sarup Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: and also a decision of this Court which proceeds upon the same view. Thus in South Asia Industries  P  Ltd. v. S. B. Sarup Singh 1  it was held that where a statute confers a right of appeal from the order of a tribunal to the High Court without any limitation thereon the appeal to the High Court will be regulated by the practice and procedure obtaining in the High Court.

precedents.case_name: South Asia Industries P Ltd v S B Sarup Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: appeal to High Court regulated by High Court practice even if from tribunal
precedents.cited_holding: where a statute confers a right of appeal from the order of a tribunal to the High Court without any limitation thereon the appeal to the High Court will be regulated by the practice and procedure obtaining in the High Court

anchor.surface_text: We would also like to refer to the decision of this Court in Naravan Row v. Ishwarlal 1  in which it was held that there is no reason for restricting the expression civil proceeding only to those proceedings which arise out of civil suits or proceedings which are tried as civil suits.

precedents.cited_proposition: civil proceeding not restricted to suits
precedents.cited_holding: there is no reason for restricting the expression civil proceeding only to those proceedings which arise out of civil suits or proceedings which are tried as civil suits

anchor.surface_text: In passing, however, we may mention the fact that a full bench of the Allahabad High Court has held in Maha Ram v. Harbans 1  that the civil court to which an issue on the quest-ion of proprietary rights has been submitted by a revenue court under S. 271 of the Agra Tenancy Act, 1926 has jurisdiction to refer,the issue to arbitration under paragraph I of Schedule II of the P C.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.141 CPC applies to issue referred by revenue court allowing arbitration

anchor.surface_text: Similarly recently this Court has held in Munshi Ram v. Banwarilal 2  that- under s. 41 of the Arbitration Act and also under s. 141, C.P.C. it was competent to the court before which an award made by an arbitration tribunal is filed for passing a decree in terms thereof to-permit Parties to compromise their dispute under XXIII, r. 3, C.P.C.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.141 CPC applies to arbitration award proceedings allowing compromise

anchor.surface_text: In a recent case Kochadai Naidu v. Nagavasami Naidu 1  Ramachandra lyer J.,  as he then was  was called upon to consider the very question which arises before us. The learned Judge held I.L.R. 1961 Mad. 413. that a proceeding before a civil court arising out of a reference to it under S. 146 1 , Cr. P.C. can be transferred by the High Court or District Court under S. 24, P.C. because it is in any case a proceedings.

precedents.cited_proposition: s.24 CPC applies to transfer reference under s.146 CrPC; it is a proceeding
precedents.cited_holding: a proceeding before a civil court arising out of a reference to it under S. 146, Cr. P.C. can be transferred by the High Court or District Court under S. 24, C.P.C.
